Epistemic Scenario: Every year everybody has to have in mind to go to the cemitery on the 2nd of November

Text: "Ogn'anno, il due novembre, c'è l'usanza per i defunti andare al Cimitero. Ognuno ll'adda fà chesta crianza; ognuno adda tené chistu penziero. "
Ironic Text: N/A
Sincerity Text: "Ogn'anno, il due novembre, c'è l'usanza per i defunti andare al Cimitero. Ognuno ll'adda fà chesta crianza; ognuno adda tené chistu penziero. "

Creator: de_Cursits_(Totò)

Epistemic Scenario: Dead people shouldn't care about where they are buried
Observable Scenario: Two dead people are fighting cause the richer one wants to be far away from the poorer man.
Text: "<<Lurido porco! Come ti permetti paragonarti a me ch’ebbi natali illustri, nobilissimi e perfetti, da fare invidia a Principi Reali?>>  <<tu qua’ nòatale, Pasca e Pifanìa!!! T’o vvuo’ mettere ‘ncapo, ‘int’a cervella che staje malato ancora ‘e fantasia? ‘A morte ‘o ssaje ched’è? E’ ‘na livella:  ‘nu rre, ‘nu maggistrato, ‘nu grand’ommo, trasenno ‘stu canciello ha fatt’o punto c’ha perzo tutto, ‘a vita e pur’o nomme. Tu nun t’he’ fatto ancora chistu cunto?  Perciò, stamme a ssentì, nun fa’ ‘o restivo, suppuorteme vicino, che te ‘mporta? ‘Sti ppagliacciate ‘e ffanno sul’e vive: nuje simme serje… appartenimmo a morte!>"
Ironic Text: "<<Lurido porco! Come ti permetti paragonarti a me ch’ebbi natali illustri, nobilissimi e perfetti, da fare invidia a Principi Reali?>>  <<tu qua’ nòatale, Pasca e Pifanìa!!! T’o vvuo’ mettere ‘ncapo, ‘int’a cervella che staje malato ancora ‘e fantasia? ‘A morte ‘o ssaje ched’è? E’ ‘na livella:  ‘nu rre, ‘nu maggistrato, ‘nu grand’ommo, trasenno ‘stu canciello ha fatt’o punto c’ha perzo tutto, ‘a vita e pur’o nomme. Tu nun t’he’ fatto ancora chistu cunto?  Perciò, stamme a ssentì, nun fa’ ‘o restivo, suppuorteme vicino, che te ‘mporta? ‘Sti ppagliacciate ‘e ffanno sul’e vive: nuje simme serje… appartenimmo a morte!>"
hasTranslation:
“Filthy pig! How dare you compare yourself to me,
born of illustrious, noble, and perfect lineage
enough to make royal princes envious?”

“Your lineage, Easter and Epiphany, my foot!
Get it through your head,
you’re still sick with fantasies!
Do you know what death is? It’s a leveler:
a king, a judge, a great man
once he’s passed through this gate,
he’s lost everything: life, and even his name.
Haven’t you figured that out yet?
So listen to me, don’t be stubborn;
put up with me here beside you what do you care?
These clownish acts are for the living:
we are serious… we belong to death!”
Creator: deCursits(Totò)

Epistemic Scenario: The poet seems to insult the wife because he is comparing her to any kind of animal
Observable Scenario: The poet describes his wife like other poets do, but in a reversed way: instead of comparing her to noble or idealized creatures, he likens her to simple, everyday animals. In reality, he is describing her as if he was a child, with pure and innocent love.
Text:
"Tu sei come una giovane
una bianca pollastra.
Le si arruffano al vento
le piume, il collo china
per bere, e in terra raspa;
ma, nell'andare, ha il lento
tuo passo di regina,
ed incede sull'erba
pettoruta e superba. [...]"
Ironic Text:
"Tu sei come una giovane
una bianca pollastra.
Le si arruffano al vento
le piume, il collo china
per bere, e in terra raspa;
ma, nell'andare, ha il lento
tuo passo di regina,
ed incede sull'erba
pettoruta e superba. [...]"
hasTranslation:
"You are like a young,
white hen.
Her feathers ruffle in the wind,
she bends her neck
to drink, and scratches the ground;
but as she walks, she has
your slow, regal step,
and moves over the grass,
proud and full-chested.
Creator: Saba

Epistemic Scenario: The poet is inviting his friend to dinner pretending to offer him a lot of things
Observable Scenario: In reality, the poet is inviting his friend and he is asking him to bring with him what it is needed to have dinner
Text:
"Cenabis bene, mi Fabulle, apud me
paucis, si tibi di favent, diebus,
si tecum attuleris bonam atque magnam
cenam, non sine candida puella
et vino et sale et omnibus cachinnis."
Ironic Text:
"Cenabis bene, mi Fabulle, apud me
paucis, si tibi di favent, diebus,
si tecum attuleris bonam atque magnam
cenam, non sine candida puella
et vino et sale et omnibus cachinnis."
hasTranslation:
"You’ll dine well, my dear Fabullus, at my place
in a few days, if the gods favor you,
provided that you bring with you a good and big
dinner — not without a fair girl,
and wine, and wit, and all kinds of laughter."
Target Description: The poet makes fun of the poor situation he is in but still invites his friend in a ironic way
Creator: Catullus

Epistemic Scenario: People are always ready to criticize you, especially online, insulting and saying "ddaeng" (slang for "wrong!" in korean).
Observable Scenario: They flip the insult "ddaeng" back at their critics with genius wordplay and rythmical onomatopeia; showing how the same word can have different meanings like "invincible" in a korean card game and that's how the artists make the haters' words seem useless.
Text:
"힙합? 땡
Rap style? 땡
걍 랩퍼, 땡
방탄, 땡 [...] 
일팔, 일삼, 삼팔, 땡
You wrong, me right, 잘 봐 땡
학교종 울려라, brr, brr, 땡
야 이번 생은 글렀어, 넌 땡"
Ironic Text:
"힙합? 땡
Rap style? 땡
걍 랩퍼, 땡
방탄, 땡 [...] 
일팔, 일삼, 삼팔, 땡
You wrong, me right, 잘 봐 땡
학교종 울려라, brr, brr, 땡
야 이번 생은 글렀어, 넌 땡"
hasTranslation:
"Hip-hop? Ddaeng
Rap style? Ddaeng
Just a rapper, ddaeng
Bangtan = Ddaeng [...]
One-eight, one-three, three-eight, ddaeng
You wrong, me right, look carefully, ddaeng
Ring the school bell, brr brr, ddaeng
Hey, your life’s over, you’re ddaeng"
Creator: BTS

Epistemic Scenario: The regime is destroying “books with harmful knowledge,” meaning works considered dangerous or oppositional.

"Als das Regime befahl, Bücher mit schädlichem Wissen
öffentlich zu verbrennen und überall
Ochsen gezwungen wurden, Karren mit Büchern zu den Scheiterhaufen zu ziehen,
entdeckte ein verjagter Dichter, einer der besten,
die Liste der Verurteilten,
entsetzt, dass seine Bücher vergessen waren."
Ironic Text: N/A
Sincerity Text:
"Als das Regime befahl, Bücher mit schädlichem Wissen
öffentlich zu verbrennen und überall
Ochsen gezwungen wurden, Karren mit Büchern zu den Scheiterhaufen zu ziehen,
entdeckte ein verjagter Dichter, einer der besten,
die Liste der Verurteilten,
entsetzt, dass seine Bücher vergessen waren."
hasTranslation:
"When the regime ordered that books with harmful knowledge
be publicly burned, and everywhere
oxen were forced to drag carts full of books to the bonfires,
a banished poet, one of the best,
discovered, among the condemned,
that his own books had been forgotten."
Creator: Brecht

Epistemic Scenario: A poet usually doesn't want his books to be burnt
Observable Scenario: The poet feels insulted that his books weren’t banned, because being condemned by a corrupt regime would confirm his integrity.
Text:
"Verbrennt mich! schrieb er mit fliegender Feder, verbrennt mich!

Tut mir das nicht an! Laßt mich nicht übrig! Habe ich nicht

Immer die Wahrheit berichtet in meinen Büchern? Und jetzt

Werd ich von euch wie ein Lügner behandelt!"
Ironic Text:
"Verbrennt mich! schrieb er mit fliegender Feder, verbrennt mich!

Tut mir das nicht an! Laßt mich nicht übrig! Habe ich nicht

Immer die Wahrheit berichtet in meinen Büchern? Und jetzt

Werd ich von euch wie ein Lügner behandelt!"
hasTranslation:
""Burn me!", he wrote about flight, "burn me!
Do not do me this wrong! Do not leave me out! Perhaps
I have not always declared the truth in my books?""
Creator: Brecht

"난 뱁새다리 (다리), 넌 황새다리 (새다리)
걔넨 말하지, "내 다린 백만 불짜리" (불짜리)
내 게 짧은데 어찌 같은 종목 하니? (What?)
They say, "똑같은 초원이면 괜찮잖니"
 (Never, never, woo)"
Ironic Text: N/A

"난 뱁새다리 (다리), 넌 황새다리 (새다리)
걔넨 말하지, "내 다린 백만 불짜리" (불짜리)
내 게 짧은데 어찌 같은 종목 하니? (What?)
